awd_titl_txt: Non-Hermitian nanophotonics for efficient thermophotovoltaic energy conversion
awd_abstract_narration:
Meeting the rising global energy need with clean and efficient energy systems is one of the greatest technological challenges of our time. Efficient conversion of heat and light to electricity is crucial in overcoming this challenge. Thermophotovoltaics is a promising technique for efficiently converting heat to electricity via light without any moving parts. The heat generated from industrial processes, nuclear fission reaction, automobile exhaust or absorption of sunlight results in thermal light radiating from hot surfaces. Photovoltaic conversion of this thermal light to electricity as in solar cells is called thermophotovoltaic conversion. The theoretical efficiency limit of thermophotovoltaic systems can be as high as 80%, though experimental demonstrations lie far below this number. The primary reason for low efficiency is the broadband nature of thermal light radiating from hot surfaces. Squeezing thermal light into a narrow band of frequencies is a challenging task especially when operating at high temperatures. This project aims to develop novel strategies to confine thermal light to a narrow band of frequencies and demonstrate efficient conversion of heat to light. Successful implementation of the project will result in discovering new tools to achieve extreme control on the flow of light and heat, educate and train next-generation scientists, and develop an efficient heat-to-electricity conversion technology for energy generation and storage applications. Given that the on-grid industrial waste heat alone is nearly 20% of the total industrial energy consumption, efficient thermophotovoltaic systems can make a huge impact in meeting the clean energy needs of the planet.
Technical description: Thermal radiation from hot surfaces is typically broadband in nature and limit the overall efficiency of thermophotovoltaic conversion. Confining thermal radiation to a narrow spectral band is the key to this problem. Previous attempts have investigated various nanophotonic principles to design narrowband thermal emitters or selective emitters, though their performance is still inadequate. All nanostructured optical materials degrade at high temperatures. Their optical losses significantly increase with temperature and limit the maximum possible spectral selectivity. Calculations show that a spectral contrast of at least 20 dB is required for efficient thermophotovoltaic conversion. Such high contrast over broad infrared wavelengths is not possible by conventional approach due to high optical losses in the constituent materials. Here in this project, an unorthodox approach using non-Hermitian physics or quantum optical description of resonant emitters is adopted to design thermal emitters. Unlike the conventional approach, non-Hermitian design exploits high optical losses in materials to simultaneously achieve high contrast and high emissivity. Further, a quantum optical description of the selective emitter allows its design as a system of coupled multiple nanoscale resonators. Such an approach is a paradigm shift in the design of selective emitters allowing novel many-body physical phenomena to be observed in thermal emission. As a result, new design tools such as symmetry, topology and internal phase of resonators present an unprecedented opportunity to extreme-engineer thermal emitters. This project aims to investigate the effect of these new design tools on the spatial and spectral properties of thermal radiation, build selective emitters with high contrast, directionality, and brightness, and demonstrate high-efficiency thermophotovoltaic conversion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
1. Accomplishments

1A. Major Goals

The end objective of the scientific investigation is to develop a non-Hermitian description of selective thermal emitters for thermophotovoltaic applications.

1B.  Accomplishments under these goals  

 1B1. Major Activities:

1)    Designing and fabrication of a non-Hermitian thermal emitter

2)    Building a thermophotovoltaic (TPV) energy conversion system

3)    Characterizing the thermal emitter and the thermophotovoltaic system

4)    Educational activity

 

1B2. Specific Objectives:

1)    Design a non-Hermitian thermal emitter with its emission peak at 1.6 micron wavelength so as to match the bandgap of a GaSb PV cell

2)    Fabricate and demonstrate thermal stability of the non-Hermitian thermal emitting metasurface.

3)    Build and demonstrate thermophotovoltaic energy conversion system employing the non-Hermitian thermal emitter.

4)    Identify the limits to the performance of the thermal emitter and the thermophotovoltaic system.

5)    Training an undergraduate student and a graduate student as future scientists

 

1B3. Significant Results:

1)    A non-Hermitian metasurface based on a quasi-BIC (bound state in the continuum) mode in a dielectric resonator coupled to a plasmonic image mode in a ground plane of tungsten was demonstrated (Fig. 1). The passive parity-time symmetric system was chosen to operate in the broken symmetry regime where the peak of resonance was observed at 1.6 micron wavelength.

2)    The as-fabricated non-Hermitian thermal emitter showed its intact functionality at 1273 K (see Fig. 2). A slight red-shift in the resonance observed at high temperatures was due to the temperature dependent optical properties of the materials.

3)  A comparison against previously reported selective emitters (Fig. 3) shows that the non-Hermitian emitter has the best performance among metal-based designs. The only design to excel the non-Hermitian design is an all-dielectric emitter, unsuitable for thermophotovoltaic applications. Thus, our non-Hermitian thermal emitter is the best practical emitter for TPV applications.

4)    A thermophotovoltaic energy conversion system was built in the PI’s lab where an electrically heated thermal emitter was placed in a vacuum chamber (See Fig. 4). The emitter faced a commercially available GaSb low bandgap PV cell. The power generated by the PV cell was extracted via electrical throughs and analyzed using a source measuring unit. 

 

1B4.  Key outcomes or Other achievements:

1)    One journal publication

2)    Two seminars/departmental colloquia

3)    Three invited conference talks and two contributed conference talks

 

1C. Opportunities for training and professional development

1)    Training a graduate student and one undergraduate student as future scientists

2)    PI-Naik co-founded an energy startup and headed it as a CTO during 09/2023-03/2024.

3)    Graduate students enrolled in ELEC 562 course during Fall 2023, learnt the basics of non-Hermitian nanophotonics and its impact on energy technologies

1D.  Result dissemenation

1)    A journal publication is pending decision. Upon its publication, a PDF copy of the article will be made available on PI’s lab webpage

2)    PI’s webpage summarizes the findings of this work

3)    Conference talks and poster presentation by the students and the PI

4)    Including the findings of this project in the ELEC 566 and ELEC 562 courses taught at Rice University

 

2. Products

 Nothing to report.

 

3. Participants/Organizations

3B. What Individuals have worked on the project?

Gururaj Naik
Email: guru@rice.edu
Most Senior Project Role: PI
Nearest Person Month Worked: 2

Contribution to the Project: Planning, execution, dissemination of results, and mentoring students
Funding Support: This NSF award and Rice University.

 

Ciril Samuel Prasad
Email: csp7@rice.edu
Most Senior Project Role: Graduate Student
Nearest Person Month Worked: 3
Contribution to the Project: Non-Hermitian metasurfaces for thermophotovoltaics 

Funding Support: This NSF award.

 

Name: Chacko Mathai

Email: cm92@rice.edu
Most Senior Project Role: Undergraduate student

Nearest Person Month Worked: 6
Contribution to the Project: Analysis of the experimental results on thermophotovoltaic system

Funding Support: None

 

4. Impact

4A. Impact on the development of the principal discipline of the project?

The demonstration shows that coupled resonators are better than single resonator designs in relaxing trade-offs between various performance parameters. This demonstration is the first of its kind in nanophotonics and enables a new approach toward designing light emitters or absorbers.

4B. Impact on other disciplines

Displays, imaging, virtual reality, and quantum optical information processing are a few applications that benefit by the formulation developed here.

4C. Development of human resources

Graduate students supported by this project gained research experience in nanofabrication, optical characterization, optical materials, thermophotovoltaic systems, and energy conversion.

4D. Impact on teaching and education

The findings of this work enriched the curriculum of a graduate level course. Also, the project provided an undergraduate student and a graduate student, the opportunity to be trained as future scientists.

4E. Impact on physical resources

A thermophotovoltaic conversion system was built and nanostructured thermal emitter samples were fabricated.

4F. Impact on institutional resources

The project supported the shared nanofabrication facility at Rice University.

4H. Impact on technology transfer

The insights developed here inspired the PI to co-found an energy startup.

1. Accomplishments


1A. Major Goals


The end objective of the scientific investigation is to develop a non-Hermitian description of selective thermal emitters for thermophotovoltaic applications.
1B. Accomplishments under these goals


1B1. Major Activities:

2) Building a thermophotovoltaic (TPV) energy conversion system

4) Identify the limits to the performance of the thermal emitter and the thermophotovoltaic system.

The passive parity-time symmetric system was chosen to operate in the broken symmetry regime where the peak of resonance was observed at 1.6 micron wavelength.


2) The as-fabricated non-Hermitian thermal emitter showed its intact functionality at 1273 K (see Fig. 2). A slight red-shift in the resonance observed at high temperatures was due to the temperature dependent optical properties of the materials.


3) A comparison against previously reported selective emitters (Fig. 3) shows that the non-Hermitian emitter has the best performance among metal-based designs. The only design to excel the non-Hermitian design is an all-dielectric emitter, unsuitable for thermophotovoltaic applications. 4) A thermophotovoltaic energy conversion system was built in the PIs lab where an electrically heated thermal emitter was placed in a vacuum chamber (See Fig. 4).
